title: The 'scam' behind the nightmarish Russian gulag inmate's artwork that ended up in a London gallery
text:
At a Soviet psychiatric ward in the late 1940s, a former gulag prisoner named Foma Jaremtschuk began drawing elaborate, nightmarish images of humanistic forms being boiled, burned and ground into meat in tortuous machines.

The scraps of wallpaper on which he drew were hidden away by his doctor for fear of retribution, and it was only years after his death that a collector discovered this shocking visual chronicle of a life broken by the Soviet state. Mr Jaremtschuk's drawings began to be sold for as much as £6,000 a piece by galleries focusing on “outsider art,” as the work of self-taught or mentally ill artists is often called, including Henry Boxer's in London.

It was an astonishing story,...
